explanation: In Sweden, people organize their lives by week numbers. 'Let's meet week 42' is more common than giving a specific date.
Midsummer is Sweden's biggest celebration after Christmas. Families dance around a flower-decorated maypole and celebrate the longest day.
Swedish children dress as Easter witches and go door-to-door exchanging drawings for candy.
Every Christmas, Gävle builds a giant straw goat. Despite guards, vandals have burned it down over half the years since 1966.
Sweden's tax authority must approve all baby names. Names that could cause offense to the child are rejected.
Fika is the Swedish tradition of taking a break for coffee and pastries. It's a protected social ritual to slow down and connect.

text: Lagom: not too much, not too little
explanation: Lagom means 'just the right amount.' It influences everything from portion sizes to work-life balance in Swedish culture.

text: Cash is weird here. Cards only.
explanation: Sweden is nearly cashless. Many shops refuse cash. Mobile payment app Swish is used for everything.
Kanelbullens dag celebrates the Swedish cinnamon bun on October 4th. Millions of kanelbullar are consumed nationwide.
In 1909, Sweden became the first European country to establish national parks. Today there are 30 national parks.

text: Midnight sun: it never sets up north
explanation: Above the Arctic Circle in northern Sweden, the sun never sets during summer. 24-hour daylight from May to July.
IKEA revolutionized furniture with flat-pack design in 1956. An employee removed table legs to fit it in his car.
Swedes drink more coffee per capita than almost any other nation - about 4 cups daily. Swedish coffee is notably stronger.
Surströmming is fermented Baltic herring with a smell so intense it's banned on many airlines.
During Christmas, Swedes drink Julmust - the only country where Coke loses its top spot seasonally.

text: A king died from eating too many semla
explanation: King Adolf Frederick died in 1771 after eating 14 servings of semla (cream-filled buns).
Alfred Nobel invented dynamite in Stockholm. Disturbed by being called 'merchant of death,' he created the Nobel Prize.
Volvo engineer Nils Bohlin invented the modern seatbelt in 1959. Volvo made the patent free for all. It's saved over a million lives.
Spotify was founded in Stockholm in 2006. Sweden's strong music scene created the perfect environment for the streaming revolution.

text: Bluetooth named after a Danish king
explanation: Bluetooth technology is named after Harald 'Bluetooth' Gormsson, a 10th-century Danish king who united Denmark and Norway. The logo combines his runic initials.
Sweden has maintained over 200 years of peace, the longest of any nation. This neutrality helped it avoid both World Wars.
In 1974, North Korea ordered 1,000 Volvos and never paid. Sweden sends invoices twice a year; North Korea ignores them.

text: Donald Duck on TV every Christmas Eve
explanation: Since 1959, Swedes watch Donald Duck at 3 PM on Christmas Eve. About half the population tunes in.
Vietnamese egg coffee was invented in 1946 when milk was scarce. Whisked egg yolk creates a creamy, custard-like layer atop strong coffee.
Nguyen is used by about 40% of the population. It became widespread when the Nguyen dynasty encouraged people to adopt the royal surname.
Vietnamese has 6 tones. The same syllable can mean ghost, mother, rice seedling, tomb, horse, or 'but' - depending on the tone.
Ha Long Bay contains nearly 2,000 limestone karsts rising from emerald waters. Legend says a dragon created the bay.
Vietnam has over 45 million motorbikes - nearly one for every two people. Streets are rivers of motorbikes.
In Vietnam, honking is communication, not aggression. A honk means 'I'm passing' or 'I'm here.'
Son Doong Cave in Vietnam is the world's largest, with chambers big enough to fit a 747 airplane. It has its own weather system.
Britain drinks about 100 million cups of tea every day - over 36 billion cups per year. Tea is a national institution.
The British queue for everything and consider queue-jumping a serious social offense. Orderly queuing is civilization.
Technically, dying in Parliament is forbidden because it would entitle the deceased to a state funeral.

text: Tower ravens: lose them, lose kingdom
explanation: Legend says if ravens leave the Tower of London, the kingdom will fall. Seven ravens live there today.

text: Cheese rolling: down a steep hill
explanation: Every year at Cooper's Hill, people chase a 9-pound cheese wheel down a nearly vertical slope. The cheese reaches 70mph.
The flight between Westray and Papa Westray in Scotland takes just 47 seconds - the world's shortest scheduled flight at only 2.7 km.
Stonehenge was built around 3000 BC, making it older than the Egyptian pyramids. How they moved 25-ton stones remains a mystery.
British scientist Tim Berners-Lee invented the World Wide Web in 1989. He made it freely available, asking for no royalties.

text: Big Ben is the bell, not the tower
explanation: Big Ben is the name of the 13.5-ton bell inside the Elizabeth Tower at Westminster.

text: Black cabs: drivers know every street
explanation: London taxi drivers must pass 'The Knowledge' - memorizing 25,000 streets. It takes 3-4 years to learn.
The United States has no official language at the federal level. Over 350 languages are spoken nationwide.

text: Alaska: 2 cents per acre from Russia
explanation: In 1867, the US bought Alaska from Russia for $7.2 million - about 2 cents per acre. Then they found gold and oil.
American tipping culture exists because restaurant workers' minimum wage can be as low as $2.13/hour.
The Grand Canyon was carved by the Colorado River over 6 million years, exposing 2 billion years of Earth's history.
Apollo 11 landed on the Moon on July 20, 1969. Neil Armstrong's first words were heard by 600 million people live.
Yellowstone became the world's first national park in 1872. It sits atop a supervolcano and contains half of Earth's geysers.
Hygge is the Danish art of creating warmth and togetherness. Candles, blankets, and good company define this untranslatable concept.
LEGO produces over 300 million tiny tires annually, making it the world's largest tire manufacturer by unit count.
Denmark flies the Dannebrog flag for birthdays, graduations, and any celebration. It's the world's oldest state flag, dating to 1219.
Danish open-faced sandwiches are elaborate culinary creations with specific rules about toppings, layering, and presentation.
Copenhagen has more bikes than people. Over 60% of residents commute by bicycle on 400+ km of dedicated bike lanes.
Danish Vikings were legendary seafarers who reached England, France, and the Mediterranean. They founded the Danelaw in England.
Copenhagen's Tivoli Gardens, opened in 1843, directly inspired Walt Disney to create Disneyland after his visit in 1951.
In Denmark, 'Danish pastries' are called wienerbrød (Vienna bread) because Austrian bakers introduced them in the 1840s.
Denmark consistently ranks among the world's happiest countries. Free healthcare, education, and strong social bonds contribute.
Norway has over 1,000 fjords carved by ancient glaciers. Sognefjord is the deepest at 1,308 meters.
In northern Norway, the sun doesn't set from mid-May to late July. Conversely, polar night means no sun in winter.
Norwegians embrace friluftsliv - spending time outdoors in nature regardless of weather. 'There's no bad weather, only bad clothing.'
Norway's sovereign wealth fund exceeds $1.4 trillion from oil revenues - over $250,000 per citizen saved for future generations.
Norwegian brunost is caramelized whey cheese with a sweet, fudge-like taste. Norwegians eat it on waffles and bread.
Norwegian Vikings discovered Iceland, Greenland, and North America (Vinland) 500 years before Columbus reached the Caribbean.
Norwegian prisons focus on rehabilitation with comfortable cells, education, and job training. Reoffending rates are among the world's lowest.
Norwegian Constitution Day on May 17th features children's parades, bunads (traditional costumes), and ice cream everywhere.
Tromsø in northern Norway is one of the best places to see the aurora borealis, visible from September to March.
Norway leads the world in electric vehicle adoption. Over 80% of new cars sold are electric, thanks to tax incentives.
Finland has about 3 million saunas for 5.5 million people. Most homes, offices, and even Parliament have saunas.

text: Heavy metal capital of the world
explanation: Finland has more heavy metal bands per capita than any other country. There are dinosaur metal bands and even a children's metal band.
Finns drink more coffee per capita than any nation - about 12 kg per person annually. Coffee breaks are legally mandated.
Finland hosts the annual Wife Carrying World Championships. The winner receives the wife's weight in beer.
Finland is called the 'Land of a Thousand Lakes' but actually has 188,000 lakes. Water covers about 10% of the country.
Nokia started as a paper mill in 1865, made rubber boots, then cables, and eventually became a mobile phone giant.
Sisu is the Finnish concept of extraordinary determination and courage in the face of adversity. It's a national characteristic.
Finns value personal space and silence. Standing close or making small talk with strangers is uncomfortable for many.
Finland claims Santa Claus lives in Korvatunturi, Lapland. The Santa Claus Village in Rovaniemi receives 500,000 visitors yearly.
Finnish schools have no standardized tests, short school days, and emphasize play. Students consistently rank among the world's best.
Iceland has over 130 volcanoes and 10% glacier coverage. Hot springs and ice caves exist within kilometers of each other.
Iceland is one of the few places on Earth with no native mosquitoes. The rapid temperature changes prevent their breeding cycle.
Icelanders exchange books on Christmas Eve and spend the night reading. Iceland publishes more books per capita than any country.
Iceland's Naming Committee must approve all baby names. Names must fit Icelandic grammar and use only letters in the Icelandic alphabet.
Over half of Icelanders believe in huldufólk (hidden people/elves). Roads have been rerouted to avoid disturbing elf habitats.
Iceland uses geothermal energy for 90% of home heating and 25% of electricity. Hot water comes straight from the ground.
Iceland's Alþingi was founded in 930 AD at Þingvellir, making it the world's oldest surviving parliament.
McDonald's left Iceland in 2009 during the financial crisis. The last burger sold is now displayed in a museum, still not decomposed.
Icelanders don't have family surnames. Children take their father's first name plus -son or -dóttir. Phone books list by first name.
Hákarl is Greenland shark buried and fermented for months. The ammonia smell is intense. Even locals need courage to eat it.
Greenland is the world's largest island at 2.16 million km². About 80% is covered by an ice sheet up to 3 km thick.
Despite its name, Greenland is mostly white. Erik the Red named it 'Greenland' to attract settlers - early marketing spin.
Greenland has only 56,000 people in an area larger than Mexico. Most live in coastal towns; the interior is uninhabitable ice.
Greenland's indigenous Inuit culture dates back 4,500 years. Traditional practices like dog sledding and kayaking originated here.
In northern Greenland, the sun doesn't set for over 2 months in summer. In winter, it doesn't rise for equally long.
Greenland produces 10% of the world's icebergs. Some tower 100+ meters above water, with 90% hidden below the surface.
In northern Greenland, dog sledding remains essential transportation. Greenland dogs are a distinct, ancient breed protected by law.
Greenland is an autonomous territory of Denmark with its own parliament. It's geographically North American but politically European.
Greenland is one of the best places to see aurora borealis, visible up to 300 nights per year in optimal locations.
Mattak is raw whale skin with blubber, a traditional Inuit delicacy rich in vitamin C. It has a nutty, rubbery texture.
The Faroe Islands have about 80,000 sheep and 54,000 people. The name 'Føroyar' means 'Sheep Islands' in Old Norse.
Traditional Faroese houses have grass-covered roofs for insulation. Some modern homes continue this practice for aesthetics and ecology.
Faroese weather is notoriously unpredictable. Sun, rain, fog, and wind can all happen within minutes. Locals say: 'Don't like the weather? Wait.'
The 18 Faroe Islands are connected by tunnels, bridges, and ferries. Subsea tunnels link islands that were once hours apart.
The Faroe Islands have almost no natural trees due to strong winds and sheep grazing. Planted trees are protected as curiosities.
Ólavsøka on July 28-29 celebrates St. Olav with rowing competitions, chain dancing, and festivities in the capital Tórshavn.
The Faroe Islands host massive seabird colonies. Millions of puffins, guillemots, and other seabirds nest on dramatic sea cliffs.
When Google didn't map the Faroes, locals strapped cameras to sheep and created 'Sheep View' - prompting Google to finally visit.
Norse Vikings settled the Faroe Islands around 800 AD. The Faroese language descends directly from Old Norse.
Faroese chain dancing (føroyskur dansur) is a medieval tradition where dancers form a chain and sing epic ballads called kvæði.
